OPERATING AGREEMENT OF SUNSET REAL ESTATE HOLDINGS LLC
A Nevada Limited Liability Company

This Operating Agreement (Agreement) is entered into and effective as of [Effective Date], by and among the Members identified on Schedule A (collectively, the Members) of Sunset Real Estate Holdings LLC, a Nevada limited liability company (the Company).

1. Formation; Name; Registered Agent; Principal Office; Term
1.1 Formation. The Company was formed as a Nevada limited liability company under the Nevada Revised Statutes Chapter 86 (NRS 86) by filing Articles of Organization with the Nevada Secretary of State on [Filing Date].
1.2 Name. The name of the Company is Sunset Real Estate Holdings LLC.
1.3 Registered Agent and Office. The Company’s registered agent and registered office in Nevada shall be as stated in its most recent filing with the Nevada Secretary of State, currently: [Registered Agent Name and Address]. The Manager may update the registered agent/office as permitted by law.
1.4 Principal Office. The principal office shall be at [Principal Office Address], or such other place as the Manager designates.
1.5 Term. The Company shall continue until dissolved in accordance with this Agreement or applicable law.

2. Purpose; Powers
2.1 Purpose. The purpose of the Company is to engage in any lawful business for which a Nevada LLC may be organized, including the acquisition, ownership, development, leasing, financing, and disposition of real estate and interests therein, and activities incidental or related thereto.
2.2 Powers. The Company shall have all powers available to a limited liability company under NRS 86 and this Agreement.

3. Members; Percentage Interests
3.1 Members. The Members and their Percentage Interests are listed on Schedule A.
- [Your Full Legal Name] – 65.00%
- David [Last Name] – 25.00%
- Lisa Kim – 10.00%
3.2 No State-Law Partnership. The Members intend that the Company not be a partnership or joint venture for any purpose other than federal, state, and local tax purposes.

4. Capital Contributions; Capital Accounts; Additional Funding
4.1 Initial Contributions. Each Member’s initial Capital Contribution, if any, is set forth on Schedule A. The Manager shall maintain capital accounts for each Member in accordance with applicable tax rules.
4.2 Additional Contributions; Capital Calls. No Member is obligated to make additional capital contributions unless all Members unanimously consent. If the Company requires funds, the Manager may request additional contributions on a pro rata basis; Members may elect, but are not required, to contribute.
4.3 Loans. Any Member or affiliate may, but need not, lend money to the Company on terms approved by the Manager consistent with this Agreement; any single or related series of borrowings of more than $100,000 constitutes a Major Decision under Section 7.3 and requires unanimous Member consent.
4.4 No Interest; No Return. Except as expressly provided, no interest accrues on capital contributions and no Member has the right to withdraw capital.

5. Allocations; Distributions; Tax Matters
5.1 Profits and Losses. Profits and Losses shall be allocated among the Members in proportion to their respective Percentage Interests, subject to adjustments required by applicable tax law and Treasury Regulations.
5.2 Distributions. Distributions of available cash, if any, shall be made at such times as determined by the Manager, pro rata by Percentage Interests, subject to reasonable reserves.
5.3 Tax Distributions. To help Members cover tax liabilities, the Company shall, to the extent cash is available and subject to lender restrictions, make tax distributions at least annually in an amount intended to allow each Member to pay taxes on allocated taxable income, assuming the highest combined marginal federal and state rate applicable to any Member, net of prior distributions for such period. Tax distributions shall be treated as advances against, and reduce, future distributions.
5.4 Partnership for Tax Purposes. The Members intend the Company to be treated as a partnership for federal and, to the extent applicable, state income tax purposes unless otherwise unanimously approved. The Partnership Representative under Code Section 6223 shall be [Your Full Legal Name] (or such other person the Members unanimously appoint).

6. Management
6.1 Manager-Managed. The Company is manager-managed within the meaning of NRS 86.291. The Members hereby appoint [Your Full Legal Name] as the sole Manager (the Manager).
6.2 Authority of Manager. Subject to Section 7 (Major Decisions), the Manager has full, exclusive, and complete authority, power, and discretion to manage and control the business and affairs of the Company, including to:
- Acquire, hold, manage, finance, refinance, improve, operate, lease, and dispose of Company property and real estate;
- Enter into contracts, open bank accounts, and hire professionals and employees;
- Pay Company expenses and establish reserves;
- Execute documents and instruments on behalf of the Company; and
- Do all things necessary or advisable in connection with the Company’s business.
6.3 Standard of Conduct. The Manager shall perform duties in good faith, with the care an ordinarily prudent person in a like position would exercise under similar circumstances, and in a manner reasonably believed to be in the best interests of the Company, subject to the business judgment rule and the limitations of NRS 86.411–86.431. The implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing may not be eliminated.
6.4 Compensation and Reimbursement. The Manager shall be reimbursed for reasonable expenses incurred on behalf of the Company. Any salary, management fee, or other compensation to the Manager or an affiliate requires approval as provided in Section 7.3 (if exceeding the Threshold) or Section 7.4 (if a fundamental action).
6.5 Reliance. The Manager may rely on information, opinions, reports, or statements of advisors and professionals selected with reasonable care.

7. Major Decisions; Member Voting
7.1 Member Voting Generally. Except as to Major Decisions requiring Member consent, Members do not participate in day-to-day management. Where Member approval is required, each Member votes in accordance with his or her Percentage Interest unless this Agreement specifies “unanimous” approval, which means approval by all Members.
7.2 Threshold. For purposes of this Agreement, the “Threshold” is $100,000. Amounts are measured per single transaction or series of related transactions within any rolling 12-month period.
7.3 Major Decisions Requiring Unanimous Member Consent if at or above the Threshold. The following actions require unanimous consent of all Members if the Company’s obligation, expenditure, or value affected equals or exceeds the Threshold:
- Incurring indebtedness, granting liens, or guaranteeing obligations;
- Capital expenditures, repairs, or improvements;
- Entering into, amending, or terminating any contract, lease, or agreement;
- Acquiring, selling, exchanging, or otherwise transferring Company property or any real property interest;
- Settling or compromising litigation or claims; and
- Engaging in related-party transactions (Manager or Member affiliated) meeting the Threshold.
7.4 Fundamental Decisions Always Requiring Unanimous Member Consent (regardless of dollar amount):
- Amending the Articles of Organization or this Agreement;
- Admitting a new Member; issuing or creating new equity interests; changing Percentage Interests;
- Dissolving, liquidating, converting, merging, or consolidating the Company;
- Electing to change the Company’s federal or state tax classification;
- Filing for bankruptcy or receivership; and
- Removing or replacing the Manager.
7.5 Actions Below the Threshold. Subject to Section 7.4, actions below the Threshold may be taken by the Manager without Member consent.
7.6 Meetings; Written Consents. Member and Manager actions may be taken without a meeting by written or electronic consent. Meetings may be called by the Manager or by Members holding at least 25% of the Percentage Interests on at least three business days’ notice stating the matters to be considered. A quorum for Member action is Members holding a majority of the Percentage Interests, except where unanimous approval is required.

8. Banking; Books and Records; Fiscal Matters
8.1 Banking. Company funds shall be held in Company accounts separate from personal funds. The Manager and such persons the Manager designates are authorized signatories.
8.2 Books and Records. The Company shall maintain books and records in accordance with NRS 86.241 and customary accounting principles. Each Member may, upon reasonable notice and during normal business hours, inspect and copy the Company’s records for a proper purpose.
8.3 Fiscal Year; Reports. The fiscal year shall end on December 31, unless changed by the Manager. The Company shall provide Members with Schedule K-1s and customary annual financial information.

9. Transfers; Restrictions; Right of First Refusal
9.1 No Transfer Without Consent. No Member may sell, assign, pledge, or transfer any Membership Interest, in whole or in part, without the prior unanimous written consent of the Members, except as provided in this Section.
9.2 Permitted Transfers. A Member may transfer to an estate planning vehicle or affiliate controlled by such Member, provided the transferring Member remains liable and no economic or voting rights are changed. Any transferee is a mere assignee with only economic rights unless admitted as a substitute Member by unanimous consent.
9.3 Right of First Refusal. If a Member receives a bona fide offer to purchase any interest, the Company (first) and then the non-transferring Members (second, pro rata) shall have a right of first refusal on the same terms. If not fully exercised within 30 days (Company) and 15 days thereafter (Members), the interest may be sold within 60 days on terms no more favorable to the buyer.
9.4 Invalid Transfers. Any transfer in violation of this Agreement is null and void.

10. Withdrawals; Death; Disability; Buyout
10.1 No Voluntary Withdrawal. No Member may withdraw or resign except with unanimous consent.
10.2 Death or Incapacity. On a Member’s death or adjudicated incapacity, that Member’s economic interest passes to his or her legal representative or estate, but no voting or management rights transfer absent unanimous consent to admit a substitute Member.
10.3 Company/Member Purchase Option on Certain Events. Upon a proposed transfer, death, incapacity, material default under this Agreement, or bankruptcy of a Member, the Company shall have the option to purchase all (or any portion) of that Member’s interest at Fair Market Value, followed by a secondary option in the non-affected Members pro rata. “Fair Market Value” shall be the value determined by an independent MAI appraiser or valuation professional mutually selected; failing agreement, each side selects one appraiser, who then jointly select a third; the average of the two closest appraisals shall control. Purchase price may be paid 20% down and the balance over up to 36 months at the Applicable Federal Rate, secured by the interest.
10.4 Defaulting Members. If a Member materially breaches this Agreement and fails to cure within 30 days after written notice, such Member may lose voting rights during the default and be subject to purchase under Section 10.3.

11. Limited Liability; Indemnification
11.1 Limited Liability. No Member shall be personally liable for any debt, obligation, or liability of the Company solely by reason of being a Member, as provided by NRS 86.371.
11.2 Indemnification. To the fullest extent permitted by law, the Company shall indemnify the Manager, Members, and their affiliates, and hold them harmless from losses, claims, and liabilities incurred in good faith in connection with Company business, except to the extent arising from fraud, willful misconduct, or knowing violation of law. Advancement of expenses may be made subject to an undertaking to repay if indemnification is ultimately not allowed.
11.3 Limitation of Liability. To the fullest extent permitted by NRS 86, neither the Manager nor any Member shall be liable to the Company or any Member for monetary damages except for fraud, willful misconduct, or knowing violation of law.

12. Dissolution; Winding Up
12.1 Dissolution. The Company shall dissolve upon the first to occur of: (a) unanimous Member consent, (b) the entry of a decree of judicial dissolution, or (c) any other event requiring dissolution under NRS 86.
12.2 Winding Up. The Manager (or a liquidating trustee appointed by the Members) shall wind up the Company’s affairs, liquidate assets in an orderly manner, satisfy creditors (including Members as creditors), establish reserves, and distribute remaining proceeds to Members in accordance with positive capital account balances, then by Percentage Interests.

13. Amendments
13.1 Amendments to this Agreement require the unanimous written consent of all Members.

14. Notices
14.1 Notices shall be in writing and deemed given when delivered personally, by reputable overnight courier, or by email with confirmation, to the addresses set forth on Schedule A or as updated by notice.

15. Miscellaneous
15.1 Governing Law; Venue. This Agreement is governed by Nevada law (NRS 86). Any dispute arising out of or relating to this Agreement shall be brought in state or federal courts located in the county where the Company’s principal office is then located, and the parties consent to such jurisdiction and venue.
15.2 Entire Agreement. This Agreement constitutes the entire agreement of the parties with respect to its subject matter.
15.3 Severability. If any provision is invalid or unenforceable, it shall be enforced to the maximum extent permitted and the remainder shall continue in effect.
15.4 Counterparts; Electronic Signatures. This Agreement may be signed in counterparts and by electronic signature, each of which shall be deemed an original.
15.5 Further Assurances. The parties shall execute and deliver such further documents as reasonably necessary to carry out this Agreement.
15.6 No Third-Party Beneficiaries. Except as expressly provided, there are no third-party beneficiaries.

questions.question: I live in Texas and just got divorced. My ex-wife and I have 50/50 custody of our 8-year-old son, Ethan. She wants to move to California with Ethan for a new job. Can she legally move out of state with our child without my permission under Texas family law?

# Texas Relocation Law - Key Points

**Short answer:** No, your ex-wife generally **cannot** move out of state with Ethan without either your permission or court approval.

## Texas Legal Framework

Under Texas Family Code, when parents share custody (joint managing conservatorship), relocation restrictions typically apply:

**Standard Geographic Restriction:**
- Most Texas custody orders include a geographic restriction limiting where the child can live
- This is usually the county of residence plus contiguous (neighboring) counties
- Moving beyond this area requires consent or court modification

## Your Ex-Wife's Options

She would need to either:

1. **Get your written consent** to the move, OR
2. **Petition the court** to modify the custody order and remove/change the geographic restriction

## If She Goes to Court

The court will consider:
- Reason for the move
- Impact on Ethan's relationship with you
- Educational and economic opportunities
- Ethan's preference (given his age, limited weight)
- Quality of life improvements
- A detailed possession/visitation plan

**The burden is on her** to prove the move serves Ethan's best interest.

## What You Should Do

1. **Review your divorce decree** - Check for geographic restrictions
2. **Document your involvement** in Ethan's life (school, activities, medical care)
3. **Consult a Texas family law attorney immediately** if she's serious about moving
4. **Do not agree informally** - any agreement should be in writing and court-approved

This is a serious matter affecting your parental rights. Legal representation is strongly recommended.

- **Demand a Modification Hearing:** The court will hold a hearing where **both sides present evidence** on whether the move is in Ethan’s best interest.
- **Propose an Alternative:** If the court is inclined to allow the move, you can negotiate for:
  - **Extended summer/winter visitation** (e.g., 6-8 weeks in Texas).
  - **Virtual parenting time** (regular video calls, shared online activities).
  - **Her covering travel costs** for visitation exchanges.

### **3. What Happens If She Moves Without Permission?**
- If she **violates the custody order** by moving without court approval, you can:
  - **File for contempt of court**, which could result in fines, makeup visitation, or even **criminal charges** (interference with child custody, a **felony in Texas** under Penal Code § 25.03).
  - **Petition for an emergency order** to have Ethan returned to Texas.
  - **Seek a modification to gain primary custody** if the court finds her actions harmful to Ethan’s stability.

### **4. Key Steps to Take Now**
1. **Review Your Custody Order** – Check if there’s a **geographic restriction** (many Texas orders limit residency to a specific county or school district).
2. **Consult a Family Law Attorney** – A Texas lawyer can help you **file an objection, request a hearing, or negotiate terms**.
3. **Gather Evidence** – Document:
   - Your **involvement in Ethan’s life** (school, activities, doctor visits).
   - The **potential harm** of the move (disruption to his routine, loss of relationships).
   - **Alternatives** (e.g., her finding a job in Texas, remote work options).
4. **Mediate (If Possible)** – Some parents reach an agreement through mediation to avoid a costly court battle.

### **5. Likely Outcomes**
- **If the court denies the move**, she must stay in Texas or leave Ethan with you.
- **If the court allows the move**, your visitation schedule will be **heavily modified** (e.g., long breaks in Texas, her paying for travel).
- **If she moves without permission**, you can take legal action to **have Ethan returned** and possibly **gain primary custody**.

### **Bottom Line**
**She cannot legally move without your consent or a court order.** Act quickly—if she’s serious about relocating, she may already be preparing a modification case. **Contact a Texas family law attorney immediately** to protect your rights.

### **Bottom Line**

- **DWI or other offenses?** → **Potential misdemeanor with jail risk.**
- **Clean record + no impairment?** → **Likely just a fine or dismissal.**

### Legal Context
- **New York State Penal Law (NYPL)**: Under NYPL § 221.05, possession of 25 grams or less of marijuana is classified as an "unlawful possession of marijuana," which is a violation and not a criminal offense. This means it is treated more like a traffic violation than a criminal charge.

- **NYPL § 221.10**: Possession of more than 25 grams but less than 2 ounces (56.6 grams) of marijuana is classified as a "misdemeanor" (unlawful possession of marijuana in the fifth degree). However, for first-time offenders, the penalties are generally less severe.

### Your Specific Case
- **30 grams of Marijuana**: Since you were found with 30 grams, which is more than 25 grams but less than 2 ounces, you would be charged with a violation of NYPL § 221.10, which is a misdemeanor.

### Penalties
- **First-Time Offender**: As a first-time offender with a clean record, the penalties are generally lenient. You are unlikely to face jail time. The typical penalties include:
  - **Fines**: A fine of up to $100.
  - **Community Service**: The court may order you to perform community service.
  - **Counseling or Education**: You may be required to attend a drug education or counseling program.

### Legal Representation
- **Hiring an Attorney**: It is still advisable to consult with or hire an attorney, even for a minor charge. An attorney can help ensure that your rights are protected and may be able to negotiate a favorable outcome, such as a reduction in charges or a dismissal if there are any legal grounds.

### Court Process
- **Arraignment**: You will have an arraignment where you will be formally charged and given a chance to enter a plea.
- **Plea Bargaining**: Your attorney can negotiate with the prosecutor to potentially reduce the charges or penalties.
- **Trial**: If you decide to go to trial, the court will hear evidence and make a determination.

### Additional Considerations
- **Impact on Employment and Education**: Even though the charge is relatively minor, it can still appear on your record. An attorney can help you understand the potential long-term impacts and work to minimize them.
- **Sealing of Records**: If you are found guilty, you may be eligible to have the record sealed after a certain period, which can help in maintaining a clean record for future opportunities.

### Conclusion
Given your situation and the current laws in New York, you are unlikely to face jail time. However, it is important to take the matter seriously and consider seeking legal advice to navigate the process and ensure the best possible outcome.

questions.question: I'm a landlord in San Francisco with a rent-controlled apartment. My tenant, James Wilson, hasn't paid rent for 3 months (September, October, November 2024). Total owed is $9,000. What's the legal process to evict him under SF rent control ordinances? How long will it take?

anthropic/claude-sonnet-4.5.response:
# Evicting for Non-Payment in San Francisco

I can outline the general process, but **strongly recommend consulting a San Francisco landlord-tenant attorney** as SF has some of the strictest tenant protections in the U.S.

## Legal Process Under SF Rent Ordinance

### 1. **3-Day Notice to Pay or Quit**
- Serve a proper 3-Day Notice to Pay Rent or Quit
- Must be precisely formatted per CA law
- Doesn't count weekends/holidays in the 3 days
- Common service methods: personal delivery, substituted service, or post-and-mail

### 2. **Unlawful Detainer Lawsuit**
- If James doesn't pay within 3 days, file UD lawsuit in San Francisco Superior Court
- Serve the summons and complaint (5 days for personal service)
- James has 5 days to respond

### 3. **Court Process**
- If contested: hearing scheduled (often 3-6 weeks out in SF)
- If uncontested: can get default judgment faster
- If you win: get judgment for possession + back rent

### 4. **Sheriff Eviction**
- Obtain Writ of Possession
- Sheriff posts 5-day notice
- Physical eviction occurs

## Realistic Timeline

- **Uncontested**: 5-8 weeks minimum
- **Contested**: 3-6+ months (SF courts are backlogged)
- **If James files bankruptcy or other defenses**: 6-12+ months

## Critical SF-Specific Issues

⚠️ **Common pitfalls that could derail your case:**
- Improper notice formatting
- Failure to include required SF rent board language
- Accepting partial payment after serving notice
- Habitability issues in the unit
- Retaliation claims

**Next step**: Contact SF Apartment Association or a landlord attorney **before** serving any notices.

openai/gpt-5.response:
I can give you the general process and timing for a nonpayment eviction in San Francisco under the Rent Ordinance. This is not legal advice; consider consulting a local landlord-tenant attorney because small drafting or service errors can derail an eviction.

Overview
- San Francisco’s Rent Ordinance (Admin. Code ch. 37) requires “just cause” to terminate a tenancy. Nonpayment of rent is a valid just cause.
- For rent that came due September–November 2024, there is no current local COVID-era bar to filing an eviction for nonpayment.
- The process is largely governed by California unlawful detainer law, with a few SF-specific requirements.

Step-by-step
1) Verify the basics
- Confirm the unit is covered by SF rent control and that James is a lawful tenant.
- Reconcile your ledger. Demand only unpaid base rent. Do not include late fees, interest, utilities, or other charges unless your lease expressly defines them as “rent.” Overstating the amount can void the notice.
- Make sure there are no open habitability issues that could give a defense (e.g., serious repair problems).

2) Serve a 3-Day Notice to Pay Rent or Quit
- Content:
  - State the just cause: nonpayment of rent.
  - Itemize each month and amount (e.g., Sept 2024 $3,000; Oct 2024 $3,000; Nov 2024 $3,000; total $9,000).
  - Provide a physical place in San Francisco (or at least within the county) where the tenant can personally deliver payment, with days and hours you’ll be available. You can also include electronic payment methods if you accept them.
  - Include required statutory language and an election of forfeiture.
  - Include the San Francisco Rent Board’s required informational cover sheet/statement and any Rent Board-required advisory language.
- Timing: It’s a 3 court-day notice (weekends and court holidays don’t count).
- Service: Serve per CCP 1162—personal service if possible; if not, substituted service; posting-and-mailing is a last resort. Keep a signed proof of service.
- Rent Board filing: You must file a copy of the notice and proof of service with the SF Rent Board within 10 days of service (Admin. Code § 37.9(c)).

3) During the 3-day period
- If the tenant pays the full amount demanded within the 3 court days, you must accept and the tenancy continues.
- Be careful with partial payments—accepting partial rent after serving the notice can waive your right to proceed unless you have a written, carefully drafted agreement and/or serve a new notice for the balance. Speak with counsel before accepting partials.

4) If no cure, file an Unlawful Detainer (UD) case
- File in San Francisco Superior Court. Attach the notice and proof of service. Pay the filing fee.
- Have a registered process server serve the Summons and Complaint. Personal service is best; substituted service is allowed after reasonable attempts. Service by posting requires court permission.

5) Tenant’s response window
- The tenant has 5 court days after service is complete to file a response. If served by substituted service, “service” is deemed complete the 10th day after mailing, which effectively extends the timeline.

6) If no response
- Request the tenant’s default and a judgment for possession (and for back rent if you pled it). After judgment, request a Writ of Possession.

7) Sheriff lockout
- The Sheriff posts a 5-day Notice to Vacate. After that period, the Sheriff performs the lockout and returns possession to you.

8) If the tenant contests
- You (or your attorney) can request a trial setting; UD trials have statutory priority. Discovery is on shortened deadlines. At trial, typical defenses include habitability, rent ledger disputes, improper notice language or service, and retaliation/harassment claims.
- If you win, you get judgment for possession and, if pled and proven, for rent owed. Then proceed with the writ and Sheriff lockout as above.

San Francisco-specific checkpoints
- File the termination notice with the Rent Board within 10 days.
- Attach the Rent Board’s required informational page to the notice.
- Ensure your unit is properly registered with the Rent Board and that annual fees are current; noncompliance can complicate matters.
- If the tenant is in subsidized housing (e.g., Section 8), also serve the housing authority and follow program rules.

How long it will take
- Best case, uncontested:
  - 3 court-day notice: roughly 1 week elapsed.
  - File UD, serve, and wait for response period: 2–3 weeks.
  - Default judgment, writ issuance, and Sheriff lockout: 2–3 weeks (Sheriff scheduling in SF often adds time).
  - Total: about 4–8 weeks.
- Contested:
  - Add time for the tenant’s answer, trial setting, discovery, and trial: often 4–8 additional weeks or more depending on court backlog and whether there’s a jury demand.
  - Total: about 8–12+ weeks; complex or defended cases can run longer.

Common pitfalls to avoid
- Notice demanding the wrong amount or including non-rent charges.
- Failing to provide a valid in-county payment location and business hours.
- Skipping the Rent Board filing or required advisory language.
- Defective service of the 3-day notice or the UD summons/complaint.
- Accepting partial rent without a clear, written agreement and updated notice strategy.

Practical tips
- Consider sending a demand letter and offering a short, written payment plan before serving the 3-day notice; it can resolve cases faster and more cheaply.
- If you proceed, hire a local UD attorney or an eviction service. In SF, precise compliance matters and tenants often get counsel.
- Keep detailed records: lease, rent ledger, communications, photos of any notices posted, and proofs of service.

If you want, I can outline the exact elements your 3-Day Notice should include based on your lease and payment methods, or refer you to local resources to prepare and file the notice and UD.

| Layer | Governing Authority | What It Controls |
|-------|---------------------|------------------|
| **State law** | California Civil Code §§ 1946‑1954 (unlawful detainer) and the **California Code of Civil Procedure (CCP) §§ 1161‑1179a** | The overall eviction process, notice periods, court filings, and enforcement of judgments. |
| **City law** | San Francisco Rent Board (formerly “Rent Board”) and the **San Francisco Administrative Code §§ 37‑1** | Rent‑control limits, just‑cause eviction standards, relocation‑assistance requirements, and the “just‑cause” notice that must accompany any eviction in a rent‑controlled unit. |
| **Local court rules** | San Francisco County Superior Court Local Rules | Filing forms, service methods, and scheduling deadlines specific to the county. |

Because the apartment is rent‑controlled, you cannot simply use a “no‑fault” eviction. **Non‑payment of rent is one of the statutory “just‑cause” reasons** recognized by the city, but you must still follow the procedural safeguards that the Rent Board imposes.

---

## 2.  Step‑by‑Step Overview of a Non‑Payment Eviction in a Rent‑Controlled Unit

### Step 1 – Verify the Debt & Documentation
1. **Calculate the exact amount owed** (base rent, any late fees that are permissible under the lease and the Rent Board rules, and any other lawful charges).  
2. **Gather evidence**: copies of the lease, rent ledger, bank statements, emails/texts, and any prior notices you may have given.  
3. **Check the rent‑control limits**: Make sure the rent you are charging does not exceed the legal allowable amount for the unit (the Rent Board’s “Maximum Base Rent” calculation). If you have been overcharging, the tenant could raise a defense that the over‑charge offsets the unpaid rent.

### Step 2 – Serve the **3‑Day “Pay or Quit” Notice** (CCP § 1161(2))
| Requirement | Details |
|-------------|---------|
| **Form** | Use the statutory “3‑Day Notice to Pay Rent or Quit” (available on the California Courts website). |
| **Content** | State the exact amount due, the date it became due, and that the tenant must either pay **the full amount** within three days (excluding weekends and court holidays) or vacate. |
| **Method of Service** | Personal service, substituted service, or service by posting plus mailing (the same methods allowed for any unlawful‑detainer case). |
| **Rent‑Board Addendum** | Because the unit is rent‑controlled, you must **attach a copy of the Rent Board’s “Just‑Cause Eviction Notice”** (Form 1) that explains that non‑payment is a lawful ground for eviction. This is not a separate notice; it is a required attachment that the tenant must receive at the same time. |
| **Timing** | The three‑day clock starts on the **day after** the notice is served (or posted). If the last day falls on a weekend or court holiday, the deadline is extended to the next business day. |

   - **Step**: You must serve the tenant with the summons and complaint. This can be done by a professional process server, a sheriff, or a private investigator.
   - **Timeline**: The tenant has 5 days (excluding weekends and holidays) to file a response to the summons and complaint.

### 4. **Court Hearing**
   - **Step**: Attend the court hearing. You will need to present evidence of the non-payment of rent, such as bank statements, rent receipts, and the 3-Day Notice.
   - **Timeline**: The hearing will typically be scheduled within 20-30 days after the lawsuit is filed, as mentioned earlier.

### 5. **Judgment and Writ of Possession**
   - **Step**: If the judge rules in your favor, they will issue a judgment for possession and an order for a writ of possession. The writ of possession allows the sheriff to physically remove the tenant from the property if they do not leave voluntarily.
   - **Timeline**: The writ of possession can be issued immediately after the judgment, and the sheriff will typically execute it within a few days to a week.

### 6. **Eviction**
   - **Step**: The sheriff will post an eviction notice on the property, giving the tenant a final deadline to vacate. If the tenant does not leave by the deadline, the sheriff will remove them.
   - **Timeline**: The sheriff’s execution of the writ can take anywhere from a few days to a couple of weeks, depending on their workload.

### Total Timeline
- **Best Case**: If the tenant does not contest the eviction and the process goes smoothly, it can take around 1-2 months from the time you serve the 3-Day Notice to the time the tenant is evicted.
- **Worst Case**: If the tenant contests the eviction and the case goes to trial, it can take 2-4 months or longer.

### Additional Considerations
- **Rent Control**: San Francisco’s rent control laws do not prevent you from evicting a tenant for non-payment of rent, but they do provide certain protections and procedures that must be followed.
- **Legal Representation**: It is highly recommended to consult with a lawyer who specializes in landlord-tenant law in San Francisco to ensure that all legal requirements are met and to increase your chances of a successful eviction.

By following these steps and working with a knowledgeable attorney, you can navigate the eviction process more effectively and ensure compliance with all legal requirements.

Clause 12.3 states: 'Customer data may be stored on servers in any jurisdiction where Provider operates, including outside Customer's home country. Provider makes no guarantees about data location or sovereignty.' We're a EU healthcare company (GDPR-regulated). Is this clause compliant with GDPR data residency requirements?

anthropic/claude-sonnet-4.5.response:
# GDPR Compliance Analysis: This Clause is **NOT COMPLIANT**

## Critical Issues

**1. Inadequate Transfer Safeguards (GDPR Articles 44-49)**
- GDPR requires **specific legal mechanisms** for transferring personal data outside the EU/EEA
- Acceptable mechanisms include:
  - Standard Contractual Clauses (SCCs)
  - Binding Corporate Rules (BCRs)
  - Adequacy decisions
- Simply stating "any jurisdiction" provides **zero legal basis** for transfers

**2. Healthcare Data = Special Category (Article 9)**
- Health data requires **enhanced protection**
- Cross-border transfers need even stricter safeguards
- "No guarantees" language is fundamentally incompatible with GDPR obligations

**3. Controller Accountability (Article 5(2))**
- As data controller, **you remain liable** for GDPR violations
- You cannot outsource compliance responsibility
- This clause shifts risk entirely to you

## What You Need Instead

### Mandatory Contract Terms:
- **Specific data locations** (EU/EEA preferred for healthcare)
- **Standard Contractual Clauses** if any non-EU processing
- **Data Processing Agreement (DPA)** per Article 28
- **Transfer Impact Assessment** documentation
- **Subprocessor list** with locations and approval rights

### Red Flag Language:
The phrase "makes no guarantees" is particularly problematic—Salesforce should provide contractual commitments, not disclaimers.

## Immediate Actions

1. **Request Salesforce's GDPR-compliant DPA** (they have standard versions)
2. **Specify EU-only data residency** or require SCCs
3. **Reject Clause 12.3** as written
4. Consult your DPO/legal team before signing

**Do not sign this contract as-is**—it exposes you to significant regulatory and liability risk.

Short answer: GDPR does not impose a pure “data residency” (EU‑only storage) requirement, but it does strictly regulate transfers of personal data outside the EEA. As drafted, this clause is not sufficient for GDPR compliance and is likely unacceptable for an EU healthcare controller, because it gives the provider unchecked discretion to store data “in any jurisdiction” with “no guarantees,” which conflicts with your obligations under Articles 28 and 44–49 GDPR.

Why this clause is problematic under GDPR
- International transfers: Chapter V (Arts. 44–49) requires a valid transfer mechanism for any storage/remote access in a third country (e.g., an adequacy decision, SCCs/BCRs, plus supplementary measures where needed). A blanket “any jurisdiction” clause with no commitments does not meet this.
- Controller instructions: Art. 28(3)(a) requires the processor to process only on the controller’s documented instructions, including as to transfers to third countries. A “no guarantees about data location” reservation undermines that requirement.
- Transparency: Arts. 13–14 require you to inform data subjects about third‑country transfers and applicable safeguards. If the provider won’t specify where data will be stored or accessed, you cannot meet these duties.
- Special category data: If any data reveal health information (Art. 9), you must apply heightened protections and likely conduct a DPIA. Unbounded cross‑border storage increases risk and scrutiny.
- Remote access counts: Support access from a third country is itself a “transfer,” requiring the same safeguards.

What you should require instead
At minimum, the contract/DPA should:
1) Specify locations or restrict transfers
- Either: commit to store/process only in the EEA (and, if needed, other “adequate” countries such as the UK/Switzerland), or
- Provide a fixed list of countries and require your prior written authorization for any new country.

2) Commit to valid transfer mechanisms
- Where data leave the EEA, require: adequacy decision; or EU SCCs (Module 2) with the 2021 clauses; and, if applicable, UK IDTA/Addendum and Swiss addendum.
- If relying on the EU‑US Data Privacy Framework, require ongoing certification and fallback SCCs.

3) Provide and maintain transparency
- Maintain an up‑to‑date list of sub‑processors and their processing locations; give advance notice and an opt‑out/right to object to changes.
- Notify and seek approval before moving data to a new third country.

4) Support TIAs and supplementary measures (post‑Schrems II)
- Provide information for your transfer impact assessments.
- Implement technical and organizational measures, e.g., strong encryption at rest/in transit, options for customer‑managed keys, strict access controls, logging, data minimization, and data segregation.
- Government access commitments: promptly notify (where lawful), challenge unlawful requests, publish transparency reports, and no backdoors.

5) Align with Art. 28 processor terms
- Process only on your documented instructions (including transfers), confidentiality, security (Art. 32), assistance with data subject rights, DPIAs, audits, and deletion/return at end of term.

Suggested redline language (illustrative)
- “Provider shall store and process Customer Personal Data only in the EEA, the UK, and Switzerland (Adequate Countries). Provider will not transfer or permit remote access to Customer Personal Data from any other country without Customer’s prior written authorization.”
- “Any approved transfer shall be subject to Chapter V GDPR safeguards, including the EU Standard Contractual Clauses (Module 2) and appropriate supplementary measures. Provider will supply a transfer impact assessment upon request.”
- “Provider will maintain and publish a list of sub‑processors and their processing locations and provide at least 30 days’ prior notice of any changes; Customer may object and, if unresolved, terminate the affected services without penalty.”

Practical next steps
- Obtain and review Salesforce’s current DPA and data transfer addenda (they typically offer SCCs and, for US transfers, DPF certification) and its sub‑processor list and country map.
- If you need EU-only, ask for their EU data residency option (e.g., Hyperforce/EU cloud) and ensure the contract hard‑codes it.
- Conduct a TIA and, if health data or high risk is involved, a DPIA; update your privacy notices to reflect any third‑country transfers and safeguards.
- Check any member‑state health data localization/certification rules that may apply to you (e.g., France HDS, specific e‑health hosting rules).

Bottom line: There is no blanket “GDPR data residency” requirement, but you cannot accept unlimited, unspecified global storage with “no guarantees.” The clause needs to be replaced or overridden by a GDPR‑compliant DPA that restricts locations and commits to valid transfer mechanisms, transparency, and supplementary measures.

qwen/qwen-2.5-72b-instruct.response:
The clause you've mentioned (12.3) raises significant concerns from a GDPR compliance perspective, particularly for a healthcare company in the EU. Here are the key issues and considerations:

### 1. **Data Residency and Sovereignty**
- **Data Residency**: GDPR does not explicitly require data to be stored within the EU, but it does impose strict conditions on the transfer of personal data to third countries. The clause in question suggests that data may be stored anywhere, which could include jurisdictions with less stringent data protection laws.
- **Data Sovereignty**: The clause explicitly states that Salesforce makes no guarantees about data location or sovereignty. This lack of control over where the data is stored can be problematic, especially for sensitive healthcare data.

### 2. **Adequate Data Protection Measures**
- **Standard Contractual Clauses (SCCs)**: If data is transferred to a country outside the EU that does not have an adequacy decision from the European Commission, you need to implement additional safeguards, such as SCCs, to ensure the data is protected to a level equivalent to the GDPR.
- **Binding Corporate Rules (BCRs)**: Another option is to use BCRs, which are internal rules adopted by multinational companies to transfer personal data within the group.

### 3. **Consent and Transparency**
- **Informed Consent**: As a healthcare company, you may need to obtain explicit consent from data subjects regarding the potential transfer of their data to third countries with different data protection standards.
- **Transparency**: You must inform data subjects about the potential for their data to be transferred outside the EU and the safeguards in place to protect their data.

### 4. **Impact on Data Subjects**
- **Risk Assessment**: You need to conduct a Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) to evaluate the risks associated with storing data in jurisdictions outside the EU.
- **Data Subjects' Rights**: Ensure that data subjects can exercise their rights under the GDPR, such as access, rectification, and erasure, even if the data is stored outside the EU.

### 5. **Negotiation and Amendment**
- **Negotiate the Clause**: You should negotiate with Salesforce to include provisions that ensure data is stored in jurisdictions with adequate data protection measures or to implement specific safeguards.
- **Data Transfer Addendum**: Consider adding a data transfer addendum to the contract that includes SCCs or other appropriate safeguards.

### 6. **Supervisory Authority**
- **Consultation**: If you are unsure about the compliance of the clause, it may be advisable to consult with your supervisory authority (e.g., the Data Protection Commission in Ireland) for guidance.

### Example of a More Compliant Clause
Here is an example of a more GDPR-compliant clause:

```
12.3 Data Storage and Transfer: Customer data may be stored on servers in any jurisdiction where Provider operates, provided that:
(a) Data transfers to third countries will only occur if the third country has been deemed adequate by the European Commission, or if appropriate safeguards (such as Standard Contractual Clauses) are in place.
(b) Provider will notify Customer of any changes to data storage locations that may affect data protection.
(c) Provider will ensure that all data storage and transfer practices comply with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and any other relevant data protection laws.
```

### Conclusion
The current clause in your contract is not compliant with GDPR requirements, especially for a healthcare company. You should negotiate with Salesforce to include more specific provisions that ensure data protection and compliance with GDPR.

questions.question: My startup's investment term sheet from Andreessen Horowitz includes this clause: 'The Company shall grant to the Investors a right of first refusal to purchase their pro rata share of any New Securities that the Company may from time to time propose to sell and issue.' What does this mean for future fundraising rounds?

anthropic/claude-sonnet-4.5.response:
# Pro Rata Rights Explained

This is a **pro rata right** (or preemptive right), which is standard in VC term sheets and generally founder-friendly. Here's what it means:

## What It Gives a16z

- **First opportunity** to maintain their ownership percentage in future rounds
- If they own 20% now, they can invest enough in your Series B to stay at 20%
- They must be notified before you offer shares to new investors

## Practical Impact on Future Fundraising

**Good news:**
- You can still raise from anyone you want
- If a16z passes or only takes part of their allocation, you're free to sell to others
- This is **not** a blocking right—they can't veto your fundraise
- Most VCs expect this and it rarely complicates rounds

**What to watch:**
- Timeline: Check how many days they have to respond (typically 15-30)
- Make sure it expires if they don't participate
- Confirm it doesn't apply to employee stock options, convertible notes, or other standard exceptions

## Key Questions for Your Lawyer

1. Does this right apply to **all** future investors or just a16z?
2. What securities are excluded? (options, SAFEs, etc.)
3. Does it survive if they fall below a certain ownership threshold?

This is very standard language—I'd be more concerned if a lead investor *didn't* ask for pro rata rights. It aligns their incentives to support you long-term.

openai/gpt-5.response:
Short answer: It gives your existing investors a contractual “preemptive” right to buy their proportionate share of future issuances before you sell to new investors, so they can maintain their ownership percentage.

What it means in practice for future rounds
- Allocation to existing investors first: Before you can sell “New Securities” to new investors, you must offer the existing investors the chance to buy up to their pro rata share at the same price and on the same terms.
- Potential impact on new investor allocations: If existing investors fully take up their pro rata, there is less room for a new lead to buy in. Many leads expect a certain minimum allocation; you may need to size the round accordingly or obtain waivers from existing investors.
- Not a veto on fundraising: This right doesn’t let investors block a round; it just gives them a first shot at a slice of it. If they pass or don’t take the full amount within the response window, you can sell the remainder to others (often within a fixed time window and on terms no better than those offered to your investors).
- Admin and timing: You’ll need to send a formal notice describing the terms, give a response period (commonly 10–20 business days), tally responses, manage oversubscription, and then proceed. This can add coordination time to a financing.

Key terms to check in your term sheet/definitive docs
- Who has the right: All investors or only “Major Investors” (those above a size threshold)? Limiting it to Major Investors reduces administrative burden.
- Pro rata basis: Usually calculated on an as-converted, fully diluted basis immediately prior to the new issuance. Confirm the definition.
- New Securities definition: Typically includes any equity or convertible instruments but excludes “Excluded Securities,” such as:
  - Shares under employee equity plans (and increases to the option pool)
  - Securities issued on conversion of existing notes/SAFEs or preferred
  - Warrants/options to lenders or lessors in ordinary-course financing
  - Shares issued in M&A, strategic partnerships, or equipment financing
  - IPO shares
- Oversubscription rights: If some investors don’t take their full pro rata, can others take the leftover? If yes, big investors may effectively buy more than pro rata.
- Notice and timing mechanics: How much time do investors have to elect? How long do you have to complete the sale afterwards, and can you change terms without re-noticing?
- Assignment/transfer: Can the right be assigned to affiliates/funds? That can increase the number of parties to coordinate with.

How this interacts with future lead investors
- Leads will expect a meaningful allocation. To accommodate both pro rata and the lead’s target check, you may:
  - Increase the round size
  - Ask existing investors for a partial or full waiver of pro rata for that round
  - Pre-negotiate that only Major Investors have the right, and/or cap oversubscription
- If you fail to honor the right, investors could seek specific performance or damages, so plan the allocation early.

Example
- If an investor owns 20% on a fully diluted, as-converted basis and you sell 1,000,000 new shares in the next round, they can buy up to 200,000 of those shares at the round price to maintain roughly 20% ownership (ignoring pool increases and other nuances).

Negotiation tips if you’re still at the term sheet stage
- Limit the right to “Major Investors” at a meaningful threshold.
- Clarify a narrow, standard “New Securities” definition with robust “Excluded Securities” (employee pool, M&A, lender warrants, strategic issuances not primarily for capital).
- Set short, practical notice/election periods to avoid delaying a financing.
- Consider limiting oversubscription rights or making them available only to Major Investors.
- If you anticipate needing room for a new lead, consider agreeing on a customary carve-out or acknowledging that allocations will be managed to accommodate a lead investor in a bona fide priced round.

Next steps
- Ask your counsel to review the exact language (including New/Excluded Securities, Major Investor definition, oversubscription, timing, and assignment).
- Map out, on your current cap table, what pro rata allocations would look like at the next round size you expect.
- Build pro rata and any expected lead allocation assumptions into your fundraising plan and timeline, and discuss early with existing investors to avoid surprises.

If you share the exact “New Securities” and “Excluded Securities” language and whether the right applies to all investors or only “Major Investors,” I can flag any unusual points.

openai/gpt-oss-120b.response:
### TL;DR The clause gives your existing investors (the “Investors”) a **pre‑emptive/right‑of‑first‑refusal (ROFR)** on every new security the company plans to sell. In any future financing round they can, on the same terms the company is offering to a third‑party, buy enough shares (or other securities) to keep their **percentage ownership unchanged** (their “pro‑rata share”). If they waive or miss the deadline, you can then sell to the new investor(s). In practice this means: | What the clause does | What it means for you | |----------------------|-----------------------| | **Notice** – you must inform investors of any planned issuance. | You’ll need a formal “ROFR notice” process (email, board consent, etc.). | | **Exercise window** – investors get a set period (e.g., 5‑10 business days) to decide. | Your fundraising timeline may be stretched to accommodate that window. | | **Pro‑rata amount** – each investor may buy enough to maintain their ownership % on a fully‑diluted basis. | You must calculate each investor’s pro‑rata amount before the round closes. | | **Same terms** – they must be offered the exact price, rights, and conditions you intend for the new investor. | You can’t give a new investor a better price or more favorable terms unless the existing investors also get them (or waive their rights). | | **Waiver** – investors can voluntarily give up the right. | You can ask for a waiver in exchange for a “sweet‑heart” concession (e.g., a larger share, a side‑letter, or a higher valuation). | | **Carve‑outs** – the clause may or may not apply to certain securities (employee options, acquisitions, convertible notes, etc.). | Clarify what is excluded; otherwise you may be forced to offer those securities too. | --- ## 1. How the ROFR Works – Step‑by‑Step 1. **You decide to raise money** (Series A, bridge, convertible note, etc.) and determine the terms (price per share, type of security, closing date, etc.). 2. **You draft a “Notice of Proposed Issuance.”** - Must describe the security, amount, price, and any other material terms. - Sent to each investor who holds the ROFR (often all holders of the Series A preferred that carries the right). 3. **Investors get a fixed “exercise period.”** - Typical: 5‑10 business days (sometimes longer for larger rounds). - They can either: a. **Exercise** – tell you they want to purchase their pro‑rata share on the same terms. b. **Waive** – formally decline (often by signing a waiver). c. **Do nothing** – which is treated as a waiver after the deadline expires. 4. **If any investor exercises, you allocate the securities to them** in proportion to their current ownership. - Example: Investor X owns 10 % of the fully‑diluted capital. If you’re issuing 1 M new shares, X can buy 100 k shares to keep that 10 % stake. 5. **If all investors waive (or you receive waivers), you can sell the remaining securities to the new investor(s).** - The new investors receive the same price and rights you offered the existing investors. 6. **Closing** – once all subscriptions are collected (both from existing investors exercising and new investors), you close the round. --- ## 2. Why Investors Want a ROFR - **Maintain ownership & voting power.** Dilution reduces their influence; a ROFR lets them keep the same percentage. - **Protect economic upside.** If the company’s valuation skyrockets, they can stay invested at the new price. - **Control over who else becomes a shareholder.** They can block an unwanted strategic investor or competitor from entering the cap table (though most ROFR clauses do not give a “right to block,” only the chance to pre‑empt). --- ## 3. Practical Implications for Your Future Fundraising ### 3.1 Timing & Deal Flow | Issue | Impact | |-------|--------| | **Notice & exercise windows** | Your fundraising timeline must accommodate the ROFR period for every investor that holds the right. If you have many investors, the window can stretch the “closing date” by weeks. | | **Capital readiness** | Existing investors must have cash on hand (or a line of credit) to exercise. If they can’t, you may need to negotiate waivers or “pay‑to‑waive” arrangements. | | **Negotiation leverage** | New investors know they’ll be offered on the same terms as the incumbents. If you want to give a new investor a better price or extra rights, you must first extend those same terms to the existing investors (or obtain a waiver). This can make it harder to sweeten a deal for a strategic partner. | ### 3.2 Dilution Calculations - **Pro‑rata share is calculated on a **fully‑diluted** basis** (including all outstanding options, warrants, convertible securities, etc.). - Example: - Current fully‑diluted shares = 10 M. - Investor A holds 1 M Series A preferred (10 %). - You plan to issue 2 M new Series B shares. - Investor A’s pro‑rata = 10 % of 2 M = 200 k shares. - If Investor A exercises, they’ll own 1.2 M after the round (still ~10 % of 12 M total). - **If you issue a convertible note** that later converts, the ROFR may apply to the **future equity** that results from conversion, unless the clause is carved out. ### 3.3 Carve‑Outs & Exceptions Most term sheets include language like: > “The ROFR does not apply to (i) securities issued under any employee stock option plan, (ii) securities issued in connection with a merger or acquisition, (iii) convertible debt that is not convertible into equity, etc.” If your term sheet **does not list any carve‑outs**, the ROFR could theoretically apply to: - **Employee option pool refreshes** (you may need to offer the investors the chance to buy those shares too). - **Acquisition‑related shares** (e.g., you issue shares to a target’s founders). **Action:** Ask the lawyers to clarify or insert reasonable carve‑outs (especially for the employee option pool). This avoids having to go back to investors every time you grant options. ### 3.4 Waivers & “Pay‑to‑Waive” - **Waiver** is a written statement (often a simple email or signed form) that the investor declines the ROFR for that specific issuance. - **Pay‑to‑waive**: In practice, investors sometimes agree to waive in exchange for a small “sweet‑heart” concession (e.g., a modest increase in their ownership or a side‑letter granting a board seat). **Negotiation tip:** If you need to bring in a strategic investor who wants a larger stake, you can ask a few existing investors to waive their ROFR in return for a small “finder’s fee” or a modest additional warrant. ### 3.5 Impact on New Investors - **Due diligence:** New investors will examine the cap table to see who holds ROFRs and how many shares they could potentially claim. - **Deal size:** If many existing investors intend to exercise, the amount of “new” capital you can raise from fresh investors shrinks. - **Negotiation dynamics:** New investors may request that you obtain waivers from the incumbents as a condition of their participation. --- ## 4. How to Manage the ROFR Efficiently | Step | What to Do | Why | |------|------------|-----| | **1. Build a “ROFR Tracker”** | Keep a live spreadsheet listing each investor, their current % ownership (fully‑diluted), the amount they can purchase in any new round, and the deadline for their response. | Prevent missed deadlines and ensure you know exactly how many shares you can sell to newcomers. | | **2. Draft a Standard Notice Template** | Include: description of securities, price, total amount, deadline, method of exercising, and a waiver clause. | Saves time and reduces the risk of a notice being deemed insufficient. | | **3. Pre‑negotiate Carve‑outs** | Work with counsel to add language that excludes (a) employee option pool issuances, (b) acquisition‑related issuances, (c) convertible notes that won’t convert for X years, etc. | Limits the scope of the ROFR and makes future financing smoother. | | **4. Secure “Waiver Agreements” Up‑Front** | When you close the first round, ask each investor to sign a side‑letter granting you the right to obtain a waiver for a future “strategic” round (e.g., a Series B with a strategic corporate investor). | Gives you flexibility later without renegotiating the term sheet. | | **5. Communicate Early with New Investors** | Let them know the ROFR exists and give them an estimate of how many shares will actually be available to them after existing investors exercise. | Sets realistic expectations and avoids surprises at closing. | | **6. Keep Cash Ready** | Encourage (or require) investors to have a “ROFR funding line” in place, especially if you anticipate frequent raises. | Reduces the chance that an investor fails to exercise and you have to scramble for a waiver. | | **7. Review the “Pro‑Rata” Definition** | Confirm whether it’s based on **pre‑money** or **post‑money** fully‑diluted shares. The difference can change the number of shares each investor can buy. | Avoids disputes over how many shares are “their share.” | | **8. Plan for “Option Pool Refreshes”** | If you need to expand the option pool, schedule that as a separate issuance (or include it in a round) and obtain waivers in advance. | Prevents the ROFR from forcing you to give investors the option pool shares, which could dilute founders unnecessarily. | --- ## 5. Sample Notice & Exercise Flow (Illustrative) > **Subject:** Notice of Proposed Series B Preferred Stock Issuance – ROFR Exercise Required > **Date:** [MM/DD/YYYY] > **To:** [Investor Name] > **From:** [Company] > **Details:** > • **Security:** Series B Preferred Stock, non‑cumulative, 1 % dividend, voting rights parity with Series A. > • **Total amount:** 2,000,000 shares @ $2.00 per share (pre‑money valuation $20M). > • **Closing date:** [MM/DD/YYYY] (subject to ROFR exercise). > • **Your pro‑rata entitlement:** 10 % ownership → 200,000 shares. > • **Exercise deadline:** 10 business days from receipt (i.e., [MM/DD/YYYY]). > **Actions:** > 1. **To exercise:** Sign and return the attached “ROFR Exercise Form” with payment instructions. > 2. **To waive:** Sign and return the attached “ROFR Waiver Form.” > 3. **If no response by the deadline:** The right is deemed waived. > **Consequences:** If you exercise, you will receive the 200,000 shares at $2.00 each and maintain your 10 % ownership. If you waive, the remaining 1,800,000 shares may be sold to the new investor(s) on the same terms. --- ## 6. Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) | Question | Answer | |----------|--------| | **Does the ROFR force us to sell *only* to existing investors?** | No. It gives them a **first** chance. If they all waive, you can sell to new investors. | | **Can we set a “right of first offer” instead?** | A “right of first offer” (ROFO) is weaker: you must first *offer* the securities, but you can then negotiate with a third party if they decline. The clause you have is a ROFR, which is stronger because the third party can only get the securities after the incumbents have exercised or waived. | | **What if the new round is a convertible note?** | If the note converts into equity later, the ROFR may apply to the **future equity**. Many VCs carve out “convertible debt” to avoid this. Clarify with counsel. | | **Do we have to offer the same price to the investors?** | Yes. The ROFR is typically “on the same terms and conditions” you are offering to the third party. You cannot give a discount to the new investor without also giving it to the existing ones (or obtaining a waiver). | | **What happens if an investor only partially exercises (e.g., wants half their pro‑rata)?** | Most ROFR language requires the investor to take *all* of their pro‑rata share. If they want less, they must formally waive the remainder, which you can then allocate to the new investor. | | **Will the ROFR affect our ability to raise a “strategic” round with a corporate investor?** | Potentially. A corporate investor may want a large stake that would crowd out the existing investors’ pro‑rata rights. You’ll need to negotiate waivers (often in exchange for board seats, advisory fees, etc.). | | **Can we limit the ROFR to “equity” and exclude “preferred” or “convertible” securities?** | Yes, but you must have that language in the term sheet or a side‑letter. Otherwise the default interpretation is that the ROFR applies to any “New Securities” the company proposes to sell. | | **Is the ROFR enforceable if we raise money overseas?** | Generally yes, but enforceability can depend on jurisdiction. Most VC contracts include a governing law clause (often Delaware) that makes the ROFR enforceable regardless of where the investors are located. | | **What if we issue shares to employees after the round?** | If the clause has no carve‑out for the employee option pool, you may need to offer the investors the right to buy those shares too. That’s why you should negotiate a carve‑out for “stock option pool refreshes.” | --- ## 7. Bottom‑Line Recommendations for Your Startup 1. **Clarify Scope** – Talk to your counsel now and ask for explicit carve‑outs for (a) employee option pool issuances, (b) acquisition‑related issuances, and (c) convertible debt that won’t convert for a set period. 2. **Set a Practical Exercise Window** – Negotiate a reasonable deadline (e.g., 7‑10 business days). Longer windows can tie up your round; shorter windows may pressure investors who need to move cash quickly. 3. **Obtain Waiver Rights Up‑Front** – When you close the current round, ask each investor to sign a side‑letter that they will waive the ROFR for a future “strategic” round in exchange for a modest concession (e.g., a small additional warrant). 4. **Maintain a Pro‑Rata Tracker** – Keep a real‑time cap table and a separate spreadsheet that calculates each investor’s pro‑rata entitlement for any proposed issuance. 5. **Communicate Early with Prospective Investors** – Let them know the ROFR exists, give them an estimate of the amount of shares that will actually be available to them, and be transparent about the timeline. 6. **Plan for Option Pool Refreshes** – Schedule any increase in the option pool as a separate issuance (or secure a waiver in advance) so you don’t have to run the ROFR every time you grant new options. 7. **Be Ready with Funding Sources for Existing Investors** – If a key investor cannot exercise because they lack cash, be prepared to either (a) provide a short‑term bridge loan, (b) accept a waiver, or (c) bring in a “co‑investor” that will exercise on their behalf. 8. **Document Everything** – Use clear, signed notices and waiver forms. Ambiguities can lead to disputes that delay the round and potentially expose you to breach‑of‑contract claims. --- ### Quick Example of How It Plays Out | Round | Pre‑money fully‑diluted shares | Existing investors (A, B, C) | New round size | Pro‑rata rights | Outcome | |-------|--------------------------------|------------------------------|----------------|-----------------|---------| | **Series A** (today) | 5 M | A: 1 M (20 %)
B: 500 k (10 %)
C: 250 k (5 %) | – | – | – | | **Series B** (6 months later) | 5 M (pre) → 2 M new shares @ $3 | A can buy 400 k (20 % of 2 M)
B can buy 200 k (10 %)
C can buy 100 k (5 %) | 2 M shares | Investors exercise → A buys 400 k, B 200 k, C 100 k. New investor D gets remaining 1.3 M shares. Ownership after round: A 1.4 M (≈23 %), B 0.7 M (≈11 %), C 0.35 M (≈5.8 %), D 1.3 M (≈21 %). | If A decides to waive, the 400 k shares go to D (or another new investor), diluting A’s stake. --- ### Final Thought The ROFR clause is **standard** for early‑stage VC deals and is designed to protect the investors’ economic and control interests. It does **not** prevent you from bringing in new money; it just adds a procedural step. By **setting clear notice procedures, reasonable deadlines, and carve‑outs**, you can keep the ROFR from becoming a bottleneck in your future financing rounds. If you haven’t yet clarified the details with your lawyers, do it **now**—before you start negotiating the next round—so you can move quickly when the time comes. Good luck with your fundraising!

This clause, commonly known as a **Pro Rata Right** or **Right of First Refusal (ROFR) on Future Financings**, is a very standard and important provision in venture capital term sheets.

Let's break down what it means for your future fundraising rounds:

**Core Meaning:**

*   **"The Company shall grant to the Investors..."**: This means Andreessen Horowitz (and likely other investors who sign the term sheet) will have this right.
*   **"...a right of first refusal..."**: Before you can offer new shares to *anyone else*, you must first offer them to these existing investors. They get the *first shot* at buying them.
*   **"...to purchase their pro rata share..."**: This is the crucial part. "Pro rata" means "in proportion." It refers to their *current ownership percentage* in your company.
    *   **Example:** If Andreessen Horowitz (A16Z) currently owns 20% of your company's outstanding shares, and you are raising a new round of funding that will issue 1,000,000 new shares, A16Z has the right to purchase up to 20% of those 1,000,000 new shares (i.e., 200,000 shares).
*   **"...of any New Securities..."**: This typically refers to any equity (common stock, preferred stock, warrants, options) or securities convertible into equity that you issue in the future. There are usually some carve-outs (exceptions) for things like employee stock options, shares issued for acquisitions, or shares issued upon conversion of convertible notes.
*   **"...that the Company may from time to time propose to sell and issue."**: This applies to *all* future fundraising rounds, not just the next one.

**Implications for Future Fundraising Rounds:**

1.  **Maintaining Ownership Percentage (Anti-Dilution for Investors):**
    *   **Primary Purpose:** The main reason investors demand this right is to protect their ownership percentage in your company. Without it, every new round of funding would dilute their stake unless they actively participated in each round. This right *allows* them to maintain their percentage if they choose to.
    *   **Investor's Perspective:** They invested in you because they believe in your potential. If you succeed, they want to maintain their piece of the pie as the pie grows.

2.  **Increased Capital Availability (Potentially):**
    *   Your existing investors are a known source of capital. If they exercise their pro-rata rights, it means they are contributing to your new round, potentially reducing the amount you need to raise from new, external investors.
    *   This can be particularly helpful if your new round isn't fully subscribed by new investors.

3.  **Streamlined Fundraising (Sometimes):**
    *   You already have a relationship with these investors. They know your business, your team, and your progress. This can make the due diligence process for their pro-rata participation quicker than bringing in entirely new investors.

4.  **Potential for Friction/Complexity:**
    *   **Timing:** You have to offer the new securities to existing investors *before* you can finalize a deal with new investors. This adds a step to your fundraising process. You typically need to give them a certain period (e.g., 10-20 business days) to decide whether to participate.
    *   **Pricing/Terms:** The offer to existing investors must be on the same terms (price, rights, preferences) as the offer to new investors. You can't offer them a worse deal.
    *   **Investor Decision-Making:** Not all investors will exercise their pro rata rights in every round. They might be constrained by their fund's capital, their portfolio allocation strategy, or their current view of your company's valuation or prospects. If they decline, you are then free to offer those shares to others.
    *   **Managing Multiple Investors:** If you have many investors with pro rata rights, managing the notification and decision process can become more administrative.

5.  **Signaling to New Investors:**
    *   If your existing reputable investors (like A16Z) *do* exercise their pro rata rights, it sends a strong positive signal to potential new investors that the current investors still believe in the company and are willing to put more money in.
    *   Conversely, if they *don't* participate, it can sometimes be perceived as a negative signal, though there are many legitimate reasons why an investor might pass on a pro rata.

Based on the clause you quoted from your startup's term sheet (which appears to be a standard "pro rata rights" or "right of first refusal" provision commonly seen in venture capital deals, including those from firms like Andreessen Horowitz), I'll break it down in plain English and explain its implications for future fundraising. ### What Does the Clause Mean?
- **Right of First Refusal (ROFR)**: This gives the existing investors (in this case, Andreessen Horowitz and possibly others in the round) the first opportunity to buy a portion of any "New Securities" your company plans to issue in the future. New Securities typically include new shares of stock, convertible notes, or other equity-like instruments issued in subsequent funding rounds (e.g., Series A, B, etc.).
- **Pro Rata Share**: The investors' entitlement is based on their current ownership percentage. For example, if an investor owns 10% of your company, they have the right to purchase up to 10% of the new shares being issued, allowing them to maintain their 10% stake (avoiding dilution).
- **How It Works in Practice**:
  - When your company decides to raise more money by issuing New Securities, you must first notify these investors and offer them the chance to buy their pro rata portion.
  - They usually have a limited time (e.g., 10-30 days, as specified in the full agreement) to decide whether to participate.
  - If they decline or don't respond, you can then offer those shares to new investors or others.

This is a protective mechanism for investors. It ensures they aren't diluted (i.e., their ownership percentage doesn't shrink) without getting a chance to invest more. It's very common in VC term sheets from top firms like a16z, as it aligns with their interest in supporting promising portfolio companies over time.

### Implications for Future Fundraising Rounds
1. **Impact on Dilution and Ownership**:
   - **For Existing Investors**: They can "follow on" in future rounds to keep their stake intact. This is especially valuable if your startup is growing quickly and attracting high valuations—investors like a16z often use these rights to double down on winners.
   - **For Founders and the Company**: It could limit how much equity you can offer to new investors if the existing ones fully exercise their rights. This might make rounds smaller or require you to raise more than planned to accommodate everyone. However, if investors pass, it opens doors for fresh capital.

2. **Process for New Rounds**:
   - You'll need to plan ahead: Before approaching new investors (e.g., for a Series B), you must give the ROFR holders their shot first. This can add 2-4 weeks to your timeline.
   - If the round is oversubscribed (more demand than shares available), the pro rata rights take priority, which might frustrate new investors who want a bigger piece.

I’m sorry you’re dealing with this. Yes—courts can issue emergency orders to restore access or preserve the status quo, especially in a 50/50 deadlock. Here’s the practical path.

What you can ask the court for
- Temporary restraining order (TRO) and preliminary injunction requiring your partner to restore access to company systems and prohibiting further changes to credentials pending a hearing.
- A status quo order preserving pre‑dispute control arrangements.
- If the dispute involves who controls the company, a summary proceeding to confirm directors/officers (e.g., a Section 225 action in Delaware) and, if needed, appointment of a neutral custodian to break deadlock (e.g., DGCL §226 or your state’s equivalent).

Where to file
- File in the state of incorporation. If your corporation is a Delaware entity, file in the Delaware Court of Chancery. Otherwise, file in the trial court with equitable/commercial jurisdiction in your state of incorporation (e.g., Commercial Division in NY Supreme Court, Business Court/Complex Civil/Chancery in many states).
- If your shareholder/operating agreement has a forum selection or arbitration clause, that may control. Courts often still grant provisional injunctive relief to preserve the status quo pending arbitration.

What to file (immediately)
- Verified complaint for injunctive and declaratory relief (breach of fiduciary duty, corporate governance claims, request for status quo order).
- Motion for TRO and preliminary injunction, with:
  - Supporting affidavit or declaration detailing the lockout, your 50/50 ownership, imminent tax deadlines, and harm if access isn’t restored.
  - Proposed order requiring immediate restoration of access to specified accounts (email admin, accounting, banking, payroll, EFTPS/state tax portals, password managers) and prohibiting changes/spoliation.
  - Motion to expedite and, where appropriate, request for a bond to be waived or set nominally.
- Be prepared to notify the other side; true ex parte relief is possible but courts prefer at least short notice unless notice would defeat the purpose.

What you must show
- Immediate, irreparable harm: missed tax deadlines, penalties, credit/reputational damage, risk to employees and customers.
- Likelihood of success: 50/50 owner/officer rights; bylaws/agreements don’t authorize unilateral lockout; breach of fiduciary duty.
- Balance of equities and public interest favor preserving operations and compliance.

Timing
- Same-day or next-day TROs are possible if you file early, clearly mark it as an emergency, and contact the court to request an expedited hearing. Have local counsel handle e-filing and chamber communications.

Parallel steps to mitigate the tax deadline
- Contact your CPA immediately. Ask if they can file/pay on the company’s behalf from their systems or submit protective payments.
- Contact the IRS and relevant state tax agencies today to explain the situation and ask about short-term options and reasonable-cause penalty relief. For estimated or sales/payroll taxes, you may be able to make a timely payment even if the return follows shortly.
- If you can fund a payment, consider paying an estimated amount to stop late-payment penalties from accruing, and document your efforts.

What to gather for your lawyer today
- Certificate of incorporation, bylaws, shareholder/founders/stockholders’ agreements, board resolutions, officer designations, cap table.
- Evidence of ownership and role (stock certificates, minutes, employment/offer letters).
- Emails/texts showing the lockout and changed credentials, screenshots, and the list of affected systems.
- Proof of tax deadlines and potential penalties (notices, CPA emails).
- Any forum-selection or arbitration clauses.

Important cautions
- Do not try to “hack back” or circumvent access controls; even as a co-owner, that can create legal exposure. Seek court-ordered relief.
- Preserve all evidence; don’t delete or alter company data.
- Keep communications professional; your messages may be exhibits.

If the company is a Delaware corporation
- Ask counsel to seek: (1) TRO and status quo order under Court of Chancery Rule 65; (2) if control is disputed, a summary Section 225 action; and, if the deadlock persists, possible appointment of a custodian under DGCL §226. A books-and-records demand under DGCL §220 exists but likely isn’t fast enough for tomorrow’s deadline.

Next step
- Retain an experienced business litigation/chancery/commercial litigator in the state of incorporation immediately. Give them the above documents and ask for an emergency TRO restoring access specifically to tax, banking, payroll, and authentication systems, plus a status quo order.

If you tell me the state of incorporation and where the business operates, I can point you to the correct court and any emergency filing procedures.
